qas.question: Historically, time has been closely related with what?
In which of Einstein's two theories do time and space merge into spacetime?
According to Einsteins two relativity theories, the concept of time depends on what?

answers.text: the spatial reference frame of the observer, and the human perception

qas.question: A crew in a spaceship travelling nearly the speed of light will not notice the change in what?

answers.text: in the speed of time on board their vessel

qas.question: How will the above mentioned spaceship appear to a stationary observer?

answers.text: the spaceship appears flattened in the direction it is traveling

qas.question: What have a crew's thought processes usually been related to?
What is it called when a spaceship flies though space?

plausible_answers.text: the spatial reference frame of the observer

qas.question: What does a space crew's thought processes depend on?
Flying through what makes the crew appear flattened out to each other?

plausible_answers.text: a change in the speed of time

qas.question: What will an observer not notice the change of when watching a spaceship fly by?
Historically, what has been related to clocks?
In which of Einstein's two theories do time and clocks merge into spacetime?

plausible_answers.text: the spatial reference frame of the observer, and the human perception

qas.question: According to Einstein's two relativity theories, what depends on the concept of clocks?

plausible_answers.text: the speed of time on board their vessel

qas.question: A crew in a spaceship traveling nearly the speed of sound will not notice the change in what?

plausible_answers.text: the spaceship appears flattened in the direction it is traveling

qas.question: How will the spaceship appear to an observer traveling at the same speed?

context: Time has historically been closely related with <a0_0><b5_0><b10_0>space<b10_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, the two together merging into <b6_0>spacetime<b6_0/> in Einstein's <a1_0><b11_0>special relativity and general relativity<b11_0/><a1_0/>. According to these theories, the concept of time depends on <a2_0><b7_0><b12_0>the spatial reference frame of the observer<b7_0/>, and the human perception<b12_0/><a2_0/> as well as the measurement by instruments such as clocks are different for observers in relative motion. For example, if a spaceship carrying a clock flies through <b8_0>space<b8_0/> at (very nearly) the speed of light, its crew does not notice <b9_0>a change <a3_0>in <b13_0>the speed of time<b9_0/> on board their vessel<b13_0/><a3_0/> because everything traveling at the same speed slows down at the same rate (including the clock, the crew's thought processes, and the functions of their bodies). However, to a stationary observer watching the spaceship fly by, <a4_0><b14_0>the spaceship appears flattened in the direction it is traveling<b14_0/><a4_0/> and the clock on board the spaceship appears to move very slowly.
